November 11, 2001: Fiction
THE KISS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) The wife of a coldhearted
Parisian banker conducts a long-distance platonic relationship with a Washington
power broker who is also trapped in an empty marriage.
ISLE OF DOGS, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $26.95.) When the governor of
Virginia installs speed traps on all streets and highways, an island in Chesapeake
Bay declares war on its own state.
MIDNIGHT BAYOU, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $25.95.) A Boston lawyer
abandons his practice and moves to the outskirts of New Orleans, where the
house he is renovating seems to hold terrible secrets.
THE CORRECTIONS, by Jonathan Franzen. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) A
multigenerational saga in which a mother tries to bring her dysfunctional family
together for a final Christmas at home.
BLOOD AND GOLD, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $26.95.) Marius returns as the
embittered protector of Enkil and Akasha, the king and queen of the vampires.
A BEND IN THE ROAD, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $23.95.) A widower and his
son's second-grade teacher discover that they are linked by a secret.
BLACK HOUSE, by Stephen King and Peter Straub. (Random House, $28.95.)
After a retired homicide detective living in Wisconsin tries to help the police solve
brutal murders, he winds up in a parallel universe.
THE BEST-LOVED POEMS OF JACQUELINE KENNEDY ONASSIS, selected by
Caroline Kennedy. (Hyperion, $21.95.) The former first lady's favorite poems.
THE MITFORD SNOWMEN, by Jan Karon. (Viking, $10.95.) A Christmas story by
the author of the "Mitford Years" books.
JOURNEY THROUGH HEARTSONGS, written and illustrated by Mattie J.T.
Stepanek. (VSP Books, $14.95.) A collection of poems by an 11-year-old boy who
suffers from muscular dystrophy.
NARCISSUS IN CHAINS, by Laurell K. Hamilton. (Berkley, $22.95.) A vampire
hunter confronts an evil kidnapper who threatens innocents.
SEPARATION OF POWER, by Vince Flynn. (Pocket Books, $25.) A top C.I.A.
operative must stop Saddam Hussein from acquiring nuclear weapons.
FALLING ANGELS, by Tracy Chevalier. (Dutton, $24.95.) The fortunes of two
young girls and their families in early-20th-century London.
PORTRAIT IN SEPIA, by Isabel Allende. (HarperCollins, $26.) A family saga set in
Chile at the end of the 19th century; continuing the story begun in "Daughter of
November 11, 2001
Non-Fiction
THE NO SPIN ZONE, by Bill O'Reilly. (Broadway, $24.95.) More political opinions
from the host of the cable news program "The O'Reilly Factor."
THE FINAL DAYS, by Barbara Olsen. (Regnery, $27.95.) The conservative
commentator, who died aboard the hijacked jetliner on Sept. 11 discusses "the
last, desperate abuses of power" in the Clinton White House.
JACK: Straight From the Gut, by Jack Welch with John A. Byrne. (Warner
Business, $29.95.) The recently retired chairman and chief executive of General
Electric tells his story as well as G.E.'s.
GERMS, by Judith Miller, Stephen Engelberg and William Broad. (Simon &
Schuster, $27.) A report on biological weapons and America's response to them.
JOHN ADAMS, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of
the country's first vice president and second president.
CROSSING OVER, by John Edward. (Jodere, $23.95.) A "psychic television host"
discusses his work and describes conversations he says he's had with those who
have crossed the bar.
ISLAM, by Karen Armstrong. (Modern Library, $19.95.) A history of the Islamic
faith by the author of "The Battle for God" and "Buddha."
GOOD TO GREAT, by Jim Collins. (HarperBusiness, $27.50.) Why some
companies thrive and others do not.
WAR IN A TIME OF PEACE, by David Halberstam. (Scribner, $28.) From Bosnia
to Somalia to Kosovo: the dynamics of American foreign policy during the 1990's.
FIRE, by Sebastian Junger. (Norton, $24.95.) A collection of pieces about
firefighters and other people who confront "situations that could easily destroy
them," by the author of "The Perfect Storm."
THE WILD BLUE, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A history of
the young Americans who flew B-24's over Germany in World War II.
TWIN TOWERS, by Angus Kress Gillespie. (Rutgers University, $26.) A history of
the World Trade Center, first published in 1999.
Q, by Quincy Jones. (Doubleday, $26.) The autobiography of the musician,
composer, producer and arranger.
ROOSEVELT'S SECRET WAR, by Joseph E. Persico. (Random House, $35.) An
account of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's involvement in World War II
intelligence.
